title: Telecom minister to telcos: Invest in infrastructure not just adding users
text: On the sidelines of a state-run Bharat Sanchar Nigam event in Gurgaon, Prasad also said that the telecom department (DoT) officials are in touch with the Municipal Corporation of Delhi officials on the tower sealing issue. RELATED NEW DELHI: Telecom minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has reiterated that the mobile phone operators should not look at only adding new subscribers but also need to make new investments in infrastructure and reconfigure their networks to overcome call drops problem. On the sidelines of a state-run Bharat Sanchar Nigam event in Gurgaon, Prasad also said that the telecom department (DoT) officials are in touch with the Municipal Corporation of Delhi officials on the tower sealing issue. Recently, the telecom operators had raised the issue with the telecom secretary that the MCD was sealing their cell sites without any prior notice and added that the issue was leading to poor quality of services, including call drops in the national capital. "The DoT officials are in touch with MCD and hope that telcos' payment issues to be settled soon. In the meantime, we are planning telecom tower extension to government buildings to facilitate consumers," Prasad told reporters. The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (Trai) has recently come out with a consultation paper seeking ways and means to compensate subscribers for call drops. Prasad said that the department is awaiting the outcome of consultation process, before it could arrive at any decision. "The telcos should work for consumers and make complaints redressal mechanism transparent and adopt aggressive marketing strategy and interface with people should be frequent so as it could achieve milestones," Prasad said. The minister said that revival of BSNL, a telco which in 2004 had reported an Rs 10,000-crore profit which has since slumped to a Rs 8,000 crore loss by May 2014, is one of the top priorities of the government. Telecom department is working on to make PSU competitive and professional and aims to turn it into not only profitable but also productive, the minister added. The state-owned operator has lost nearly 1.78 crore wireless and over 20 lakh wireline subscribers between March 2014 and March 2015 to private telcos. Prasad added the government has received proposals worth Rs1.10 lakh crore for local electronics manufacturing.
